item.title: Faculty Recruitment Procedures
item.dc:creator: mtowery1
item.content:encoded:
Search Committee Information and Responsibilities

The Search Committee Chair must ensure that a search is conducted according to university guidelines and procedures. The chair must secure three to five members for the search committee, which may include a representative from outside of the College. All committee members are responsible for promotion of diversity within the department. A search committee should demonstrate diverse membership, including members of an underrepresented group and/or protected class. The search committee will keep records on the  committee itself, including the chair of the committee, and the race and gender of each member. The chair must submit to the College of Law Human Resources Office an Affirmative Action Recruitment and Selection Report for each faculty search. Complete information available at the University Faculty Hiring Procedures website. Click on a section title to expand information about each phase of the faculty recruitment process. [accordions][accordion acc_title="Before You Begin"]

Approval to Search

The College of Law faculty search committee will determine along with the dean and the assistant dean for administration and finance, whether there is a need for a new, replacement or visiting faculty appointment. A Faculty Position Vacancy Form will be submitted to the Provost's Office, which will assign a vacancy log number. If approved, the log number, position vacancy announcement number and finalized form will be returned to the college's human resources department, and forwarded to the faculty search committee. The original form will remain on file in the college's human resources department.

Advertising Faculty Positions

To post a vacancy on the University System of Georgia Clearinghouse, the human resources officer and  search committee chair must write a vacancy announcement and submit a USG Applicant Clearinghouse Form. The human resources offices will manage the compilation and distribution of documents to the Office of Opportunity Development for further advertising. All applicants must complete the Confidential Applicant Flow Information Form online. The committee chair is responsible for providing the form URL to all applicants to self-identify race/ethnicity and gender per OFCCP regulations.

Advertising Policy

Faculty positions must be advertised in at least one national source. The recruiting department - not the college - is responsible for placing ads. Local outlets like the AJC and Fulton County Daily Report do not meet the national requirement. Print ads should run for a minimum of five days. Targeted ads toward minorities and/or women is required if your department has been identified by the University's Affirmative Action Plan as underutilized. All ads must contain the following:
  • Rank
  • Openings are "anticipated hires"
  • Minimum qualifications
  • Responsibilities
  • The semester and term of hire
  • Instructions for submitting applications
  • The EEO-AA statement: "Georgia State University is an AA/EEO employer."
Background contingency statement: "An offer of employment will be conditional on background verification."[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Organization and Planning"]

Recruitment Plan

The search committee should work with the human resources department to develop an appropriate recruitment and advertising plan. After reviewing the position for underutilization of minorities and women, the Committee should incorporate a recruitment plan to specifically target underutilized groups. To determine if your job group is underutilized for minorities and/or women, refer to the Underutilization & Employment Goals Chart.

Retention of Application Materials

Any document distributed or received must be retained for at least three years after the search has concluded. Application materials are handled only at the college level, and should be submitted to the search committee or the college's human resources department. You should keep an itemized list of the materials received from each candidate. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Applications and Applicants"]

Approval of Pool

To interview candidates, you must submit an Affirmative Action Checklist and Approval of Pool Form after the vacancy closing date and before the first interview. The AOP must include the name, race and gender (if known) of each candidate to be interviewed. Additional documentation should be submitted to the college human resources department:
  • A copy of the print ad and targeted recruitment ad
  • A copy of the completed Committee Selection Report
  • The CV of each candidate listed on the Approval of Pool Form
The human resources department will compile and forward the package to the Dean and to ODDEP for review and approval. Once approved, candidates may be interviewed.
Amended Approval of Pool
To interview additional candidates, you must submit an amended AOP form.
Additional Information Regarding the Approval of Pool
ODDEP can provide a tally of responses from the CAFIF upon request. All CAFIF information is maintained by ODDEP and logged according to log and PVA numbers. Interviews should be conducted after the interivew pool is approved by ODDEP and with every assurance that the University is complying with state, federal and internal policies on AA/EEO. The committee chair will be responsible for providing the committee members with an overview of appropriate and inappropriate search procedures.

Applicant Pre-Screening

Skype Interviews, Conference and Airport Interviews
Faculty Search Committees at the College of Law may engage in the practice of prescreening applicants for formal interview selection through Skype; at professional association conferences such as with the American Bar Association and Association of American Law Schools; and through airport meetings. When engaging in prescreening reviews, it is the responsibility of the Search Committee Chair to maintain accurate candidate records to include meeting dates and locations, number of applicants reviewed, gender and race, and reasons for rejection from further consideration. It is also important to maintain consistency with screening questions and disqualifying factors.[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Making an Offer"]

Selecting a Candidate

After all candidates have been interviewed (or withdrawn candidacy) and a preferred candidate has been agreed upon by the committee, the chair must complete a For the Record packet for each candidate who will be hired. The For the Record Packet includes:
  • A completed For the Record form.
  • A Recommended Applicant/Candidate form.
  • A letter of recommendation from the Dean to the Provost supporting the selection of the candidate, based upon a review of credentials (Support is required for Probationary Credit and Tenure upon Appointment Candidates only).
  • A letter of recommendation from the Chair to the Dean supporting the selection of the candidate based upon a review of credentials, fit within the college.
  • The original approved Approval of Pool form (for additional hires under the same log #, submit a copy of the approved AOP)
  • A completed Affirmative Action Recruitment and Selection Report.
  • A copy of the official position advertisement.
  • A copy of the CV of all candidates listed on the Approval of Pool form.
Once the chair has submitted these forms to the college's human resources department, it will be forwarded to the Provost's Office, and then to ODDEP for review and approval. If everything is in order, the Provost's Office will notify the college's human resources department, who will notify the search committee chair.

Extending the Offer

The college's human resources department will work with the Dean's Office to draft and distribute an offer letter to the prospective faculty member along with relevant personnel forms. The new hire must submit these forms before she may be activated as an employee:
  • Completed faculty hire packet
  • Original official transcript of highest degree earned that lists date of conferral.
  • Background Investigation Form
After the employment offer has been accepted by the candidate, the search committee chair must notify in writing all other candidates that a selection has been made.
Declined Offers
If your first choice declines the offer, you may recommend an alternate candidate. Submit the For the Record packet for the alternate candidate, using the same Log Number. Include the name, gender and race of the candidate who declined the initial offer on the Recommended Applicant Form under the section entitled "If Offered and Declined".[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Activating New Employees"]

Activating a New Employee

Employees must complete and submit to the college's human resources department these documents:
  • Faculty Hire Packet: Completed, signed and mailed to the address listed on the hire packet. Hire packets must not go to the university's human resources department. Doing so may cause delays.
  • Identification and Proof of Authorization to Work in the United States: The I-9 is required and can be notarized outside of the University.
  • New Hire ePAF: Electronic Personnel Action Form
More information for new employees is available on the Intranet: New Employees. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Visiting and Other Faculty"]

Recruiting Visiting/Other Faculty

New visiting faculty positions require a Faculty Position Vacancy Form and job description. Departments are not required to advertise for these positions unless they are underutilized. Other faculty positions have special recruitment and placement procedures that can be found in the University Faculty Hiring Procedures site.[/accordion][/accordions]

item.title: Staff Classification and Recruitment
item.dc:creator: mtowery1
item.content:encoded:
Staff Recruitment

Recruitment decisions have implications for the college's overall organizational performance and credibility. Staff recruitment for the College of Law is managed jointly by the university’s Staff Recruitment and Retention Office and the college’s human resources department. There are many steps in the process to hire a new staff person. Complete information can be found at the university's human resources site.
  • Position Development & Classification
  • Development of Recruitment Strategy
  • Search Committee Development (when applicable)
  • Applicant Tracking
  • Interview Process
  • Offer Development
  • Salary Negotiation
  • On-boarding and Training
Position Classification and Reclassification Position classification, the assignment of tasks and responsibilities appropriate to a title, takes place when a job is newly created or when there are significant changes in the scope of duties assigned to an existing position. When a position is created it is important to determine how that position will fit within the organization and what the essential duties of the position will be. When there is a significant change in the duties assigned to an existing position, it may be necessary to request a reclassification. The duties and responsibilities assigned to a position are the focus of the classification process - not the individual who is currently responsible for those tasks. A complete and accurate description of these duties serves as the primary basis for classification decisions. The classification process at the College of Law is managed jointly by the college's human resources department and the university’s Classification and Compensation department.

Reclassification Resources

Classification Packet
When making a classification request a complete packet should be submitted to the College’s HR Office which includes:
  • A cover memo from the supervisor or manager who is requesting the reclassification. A summary of the new duties, or duties and responsibilities which have changed since the last job description was written. This memo/letter should be addressed to the Assistant Dean for Finance and Administration and the College HR Officer.
  • A completed Position Review Form. The job description should either be completed by the immediate supervisor, or by the immediate supervisor and incumbent employee. If the incumbent is new to the job or the position is vacant, the supervisor should complete the job description. Otherwise, the incumbent may complete it and the supervisor, who has the authority and responsibility to determine the position's actual duties and responsibilities, should review and validate it.
  • An organizational chart for the unit or division indicating where the position fits within the College.
Classification Determination
The College HR Officer reviews the packet for completeness upon receipt. Requests are typically processed in the order received. The HR works to align the job description with University’s classification standards, makes appropriate departmental equity comparisons, determines if the recommended title is appropriate for the position, and prepares the packet for final signature and processing through University Classification and Compensation. If the job materials do not provide sufficient information to move forward in the review process, the College HR Officer will contact the supervisor to obtain additional information and/or clarification of duties.
Position Review Process
The position review process involves the examination of several factors to determine the appropriate classification of positions. Examples of competencies used in position review are:
  • Nature of Work: The type, variety and complexity of duties performed;
  • Independence: The authority or "freedom of action" vested in a position, as well as to what extent the position is supervised;
  • Knowledge: The education, specialized skills and job knowledge required for successful performance of the duties;
  • Decision Making: The criticality, impact and consequence of decisions made by the position;
  • Scope and Impact: The extent to which the work impacts the organization within and outside the organization;
  • Collaboration: The extent to which the work requires organizational collaboration and the degree of complexity involved in the collaboration;
  • Span of Control: The extent to which the position is supervisory and the nature of the supervisory responsibilities;
Job Evaluation Matrices
One of the tools used to measure the competencies present in a position is a job evaluation matrix. A job evaluation matrix is an analytical tool that outlines and summarizes the various factors that are considered when determining position title and compensation.

Information about Reclassified Positions

Effective Dates
When a position is classified/reclassified, the effective date of the classification is typically on or near the first of the month following receipt of the request by Classification and Compensation.
Salary Resulting from Reclassification
Employees may receive a salary increase if the position has been upgraded. An employee who is reclassified upward must earn at least the minimum of the new salary range. An downward reclassification with a lower salary range maximum may incur a decrease in pay to result in a salary that falls within the new salary range. Eligibility for salary change is contingent upon College of Law policy and budgetary approval.
In-grade Salary Adjustments
An employee who is laterally reclassified to a classification with an equivalent salary range does not typically receive a change in salary. In-grade salary reviews offer the option to review existing compensation for classified regular staff under special circumstances. Such increases may be permanent or temporary, depending on the reason for the action. In-grade adjustments may also include market equity adjustments and one-time salary adjustments. Recommendations for in-grade adjustments must be carefully considered by the college and university's classification and compensation office. Eligibility is contingent upon college and university policy and budgetary approval.
Department/Employee Appeal
If a department disagrees with a classification decision, it may be appealed. A written appeal along with reasons for disagreement, should be submitted to the college's human resources department for  review. Review of the appeal will typically be completed within 30 days. The appeal process does not amend a desired classification. Any revisions to the originally submitted job description will constitute a new classification request. If the department agrees with the decision but the employee disagrees, employees may request further review. A written appeal along with reasons for disagreement, should be submitted to the college's human resources department for review within 30 days of the change. Forms and Links University Classification and Compensation Department

item.title: Registrar's Office
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Contact the Registrar's Office
Rackliffe, Tricia Registrar 404-413-9012
St. Clair, Lauren Assistant Registrar 404-413-9010
 

Common Forms

  • Reduced Course Load Application
  • Request for Overload
  • Request to Change Programs
  • Independent Research Application
  • Writing Requirement Form
  • Information Request Form
  • Make-up Exam Request Form

Common Questions

Click on a heading to expand information about that topic. [accordions][accordion acc_title="Full-time Students: Required Courses"]

What Courses am I required to take as a Law Student?

Listed below are the required courses and the programs into which they fit. Schedule of all classes or only 1L classes. (To satisfy the requirements for the J.D. degree, a student must complete a minimum of 90 hours with a minimum GPA of 2.20)
1ST YEAR FULL-TIME
Fall Semester Spring Semester
Contracts I 3 credits Contracts II 3 credits
Torts I 4 credits Property 4 credits
Civil Procedure I 3 credits Civil Procedure II 3 credits
Lawyering: Foundations I 3 credits Criminal Law 3 credits
Legal Bibliography 1 credit hour Lawyering: Foundations II 3 credit hours
 
2ND YEAR FULL-TIME*
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Constitutional Law I 3 credits Litigation 3 credits
Evidence 4 credits Professional Responsibility 2 credits
Electives 8 credits Electives 10 credits
 
3RD YEAR FULL-TIME
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Electives 15 credits Elective 14 credits
*Students are required to take Evidence and Litigation in the same academic year, but may postpone taking these required courses until a year later than that recommended. All other listed courses must be taken at the earliest opportunity offered. Students may choose to take courses during the summer term. The purpose of the college's summer offerings is to provide diversity and balance to a student's course of study. Students who take summer courses will be able to reduce their load below that indicated here. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Part-time Program: Required Courses"]

Part-Time Program*

1ST YEAR PART-TIME
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Contracts I 3 credits Contracts II 3 credits
Torts 4 credits Property 4 credits
Lawyering: Foundations I 3 credits Lawyering: Foundations II 3 credits
Legal Bibliography 1 credit hour
(Summer Term - 4 credits)
2ND YEAR PART-TIME
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Elective 3 credits Criminal Law 3 credits
Civil Procedure I 3 credits Civil Procedure II 3 credits
Constitutional Law I 3 credits Elective 3 credits
(Summer Term- 4 credits)
3RD YEAR PART-TIME
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Evidence 4 credits Lawyering: Advocacy 3 credits
Electives 6 credits Professional Responsibility 2 credits
Electives 5 credits
(Summer Term - 4 credits)
4TH YEAR PART-TIME
Fall Semester
Spring Semester
Electives 10 credits Electives 9 credits
* Part-time students may accelerate graduation by taking more summer courses, or may delay graduation by taking fewer or no summer courses. There are a variety of ways to reach the 90-hour total required for graduation.
WRITING REQUIREMENT COURSES
Before graduation, each student must complete a course that satisfies the upper level writing requirement. The Schedule of Classes lists some of the courses which may satisfy the requirement. There is no definitive list of courses which meet the writing requirement. If you have questions about whether a course will satisfy the writing requirement, please contact the individual professor. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="How to Pay Tuition"]

How Do I Pay for Tuition?

Students must correctly register and pay by the last regularly scheduled registration date (check registration materials for date or call 404-413-9200) for the classes which they attend. Pay careful attention to the registration process; mistakes may result in your being registered for the wrong classes, or your being charged additional fees. Students will not be given credit for courses they attend if they are not registered for said courses, nor will adjustments be made at the end of the semester for incorrect registration. It is the student's responsibility to make certain that they are registered for the correct courses. LATE REGISTRATION FEES: Students who fail to register during the early or regular registration periods (see registration calendar) will be required to pay a late registration fee of $50.00. HOLDS: Before attempting to register, students should check to see if there are any registration holds placed upon them by the Law Library, Pullen Library, Student Accounts, Financial Aid, or any other University office. Transfer and guest students should have already cleared their Immunization Requirement with the Immunization Office. It is the responsibility of the student to clear any existing holds. Students who have not cleared holds or completed the Immunization Requirement during the early or regular registration periods will be charged the late fee. ON-CAMPUS PAYMENT: Students who pay in person should bring their fee payment to the Office of Student Accounts, Room 100 Sparks Hall. PAYMENT VIA GoSOLAR: Tuition & Fees can be paid on-line at the GoSOLAR website. To pay tuition via GoSOLAR: Login to GoSOLAR. Once logged in, go to the Student Accounts Menu and then click on the link to Pay Tuition & Fees . PAYMENT BY MAIL: Tuition & Fees can be paid by mail at the following mailing address:
GSU Student Accounts P.O. Box 4029 Atlanta, GA 30302-4029
Students who fail to meet the fee deadline(s) will lose all classes for which they are registered and will need to register again during a later phase. Students dropped for non-payment of fees after registering during Late Registration will not be re-registered. A late fee will be charged to all who register and pay for the first time during Late Registration & Drop/Add. Those who were dropped from classes for non-payment of fees will be charged the late fee if registering during Late Registration & Drop/Add.
*WE DO NOT SEND BILLS*
[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="How to Withdraw From Class"]

How do I Withdraw from a Class?

If a student drops a course during the regular registration period, or the Late Registration/Drop-Add period, the dropped course(s) will not show up on the transcript. Courses dropped after the Late Registration/Drop-Add period, but by the midpoint, will be considered "withdrawals" and a grade of "W" or "WF" at instructor's discretion will be recorded on the transcript. Courses dropped after the midpoint will receive a "WF". Students who wish to withdraw from classes after the Late Registration/Drop-Add period must complete the appropriate paperwork. The Office of Academic Services (3rd floor) will provide the student with the proper form(s) to be completed. The student must then submit the completed form(s) to the University Registrar's Office (Room 227, Sparks Hall). These forms must be completed and received in the Registrar's Office no later than the Midpoint (see the Academic Calendar). Withdrawals after this point are granted only in cases of hardship, and additional forms must be submitted. Failure to follow this procedure will result in the awarding of a WF instead of a W. A grade of WF is treated as an F (55) for the purpose of computing the grade point average. Retaking the course will not expunge the WF from the student's academic record. Students who find they must withdraw after the midpoint should make an appointment with the College of Law Registrar to discuss their hardship as soon as they become aware of the situation. For withdrawals made during the first four weeks of the semester, a portion of the student's class fees may be refunded. The refund policy has been modified by the Board of Regents; please contact Student Accounts for more information. Note the recent changes to the University Withdrawal Policy. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Checklist for Graduation"]

How Do I Apply for Graduation?

All students must apply to graduate. Please contact the Graduation Office (231 Sparks Hall), call (404) 413-2248 or see the University Graduation Office web site for information regarding graduation procedures.

Graduation Checklist

The following information is to assist you in insuring that you have fulfilled all requirements necessary to graduate from the Georgia State University College of Law with the degree of Juris Doctor.
  1. You must complete a minimum of 90 semester hours to graduate.
  2. You must have a minimum GPA of 2.20 to graduate.You may have a maximum of 11 hours of "S" (pass) credit.You must have 79 hours of graded credit.No, you may not pick which courses are pass/fail. Sorry.
  3. You must have passed all of the following required courses with a grade of D or better:
    Law 5000/5001 Civil Procedure I and II
    Law 5010/5011 Contracts I and II
    Law 5020 Criminal Law
    Law 5030 Legal Bibliography
    Law 5050/5051 Property I and II
    Law 5060/5061 Torts I and II
    Law 5070/5071 RWA I and II
    Law 6000 Constitutional Law
    Law 6010 Evidence
    Law 6020 Professional Responsibility
    Law 6030 Litigation
  4. The Upper Level Writing Requirement. (This is not RWA.) You must complete satisfactorily one substantial legal writing project during your upper class period of study. To satisfy this requirement, the student must earn a grade of at least C+ on the written portion of any two- or three credit course that qualifies as a legal writing course. While there is no list of courses that meet the Writing Requirement, they are indicated on the course schedule each semester. You may opt to do an Independent Research project for two course credits which may also satisfy the Writing Requirement.
  5. You must apply to graduate. The deadline to apply is typically one year before the graduation date. Deadline dates are posted by the Graduation Office. Please visit the Graduation Office (231 Sparks Hall) or call (404) 413-2248 for more information.
  6. When you apply to graduate, you must complete the application form, tand take it to the Graduation Office for approval. Then, take the stamped form and a check for $40.00 to Student Accounts (1st floor of Sparks Hall) to be processed.
  7. If you need to change your date of graduation, there is another form which must be completed and routed like the original request. If you file before the semester mid-point of the term in which you were supposed to graduate, you do not need to pay your graduation fee again. For more information, please visit the Graduation Office (231 Sparks Hall).
Complete requirements for graduation are listed in the College of Law Bulletin. [/accordion] [accordion acc_title="How to Order Transcripts"]

How Do I Order Transcripts?

Official transcripts are not handled at the college level, and must be ordered through the Georgia State University Office of the Registrar. Current students may access their transcripts via PAWS at any time. Alumni may request transcripts online. Visit GSU's transcript information page.[/accordion][/accordions]  

Mailing Address

Georgia State University College of Law Office of the Registrar P.O. Box 4037 Atlanta, Georgia 30302-4037

Delivery Address

Georgia State University College of Law Office of the Registrar Suite 300 - Urban Life Building 140 Decatur Street Atlanta, Georgia 30303 Directions

item.title: Business and Finance
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
This office is responsible for the management of all business affairs and operational budgetary functions for the College of Law.  The Office of Business and Finance develops and implements various policies and procedures within the College ensuring adherence to the policies of the State of Georgia, the Board of Regents, and Georgia State University. This office also serves as the College's Spectrum, procurement, and sponsored-research representative and coordinator.  We support the Dean, Associate Deans, department heads and center directors in executing their state budgets, sponsored grants, endowed and operational foundation accounts.

Contacts

Contact Mignon Jackson-Jones for:
  • management of all grant accounts
  • establishing new accounts (Agency Continuing Education, Departmental Sales and Services)
  • Spectrum access
  • Financial Edge access
  • P-card application
  • consultant agreements
  • sponsor grants
  • joint agreements
  • moving expenses
  • technology fee
  • expenditure review
Mignon Jackson-Jones Business Manager III Phone: (404) 413-9096
Contact Valencia Lewis for:
  • purchases greater than $5000 that require contracts, consultant agreements or purchase orders
  • scholarship payment requests
  • Touchnet/marketplace system
  • quarterly P-card processing
  • journal entries
  • COL Foundation accounts
  • COL student organization accounts
Valencia Lewis Business Manger I Phone: (404) 413-9098

item.title: Administrative Services
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The Office of Administrative Services handles operational and facilities needs. Expand a topic below for contact information. Emergencies All emergencies, including medical emergencies, should be directed first to Campus Security. For life threatening emergencies, call 911 first and then the Campus Security Office. Building evacuation routes are posted on every floor of the Urban Life building. Visit the Office of Emergency Management for the campus emergency plan. [accordions][accordion acc_title="Department Contacts"]

Contact

Robin Simpson, Receptionist 404-413-9000 Robin is responsible for front desk operations, mail distribution, general office supplies androom reservations. York Singleton, Facilties Coordinator 404-413-9095 York is responsible for facility-related work requests and special setups. Ken Walsh, Director of Administrative Services 404-413-9090 Ken is responsible for the facility and operations.[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Event Planning"]At least six weeks prior to your event, reserve space in the Urban Life Building through the Meeting Room Booking System. Once event details are available, create an event on the College of Law calendar. Include in your calendar request whether technology (microphone, computer access, etc.) is needed. Technology requests must be made at least 48 hours in advance and are subject to staff availability.  For event sign-in, easels or table requests, contact York Singleton at least one week before the event. Event signage is the responsibility of the event host. SIgns may be posted in the building during your event, but must be removed after the event concludes. You are also responsible for cleaning up trash and food after your event. If trash bins are full, you may contact Housekeeping at 404-413-0600. For weekend events, check out a classroom key from the law library desk on the day of the event. Contact Ken Walsh for key and building access for events prior to 9 a.m. University Police are responsible for unlocking the building; if you are unable to access the building at the pre-determined time, contact them directly at 404-413-2100.

Special Event Contacts

Classroom Reservations - Robin Simpson, 404-413-9000 Student Center and West Exhibit Area Reservations*, 404-413-1870 Table Setups - York Singleton, 404-413-9095 Technology Requests – 404-413-9111 Keys & After Hours Access - Ken Walsh, 404-413-9090 Parking Requests – 404-413-9500 Housekeeping Requests – 404-413-0600 *This venue has their own table setup staff.[/accordion] [accordion acc_title="Services List"]Contact York Singleton for:
  • Office moves
  • Recycling
  • Shredding confidential documents
  • Special Furniture setups – require at least 48 hours notice. This procedure usually involves a room reservation.
  • Records storage and retrieval - This includes exams, faculty evaluations and departmental records using the Regents guidelines for records management. Exam storage requires a form, download it here.
  • Maintenance and toner for copiers, faxes & faculty printers
  • Carpet cleaning*
  • Lighting*
  • HVAC issues*
*These items are handled by the university and require a work request. For general lights out and cleaning requests, you may call them directly at 404-413-0700. Contact Robin Simpson for:
  • Room Reservations
  • Student issuance of lockers
  • Incoming and Outgoing Mail
  • Ordering supplies for faculty and staff
  • Telephone directory and updates
Contact Ken Walsh for:
  • Telephone and voicemail problems. Click here for a telephone instructional diagram.
  • After-hours access /issuance of keys
  • Emergency evacuation procedures, coordination
  • Security Problems*
  • Office design /setup
  • Renovations
  • Security
[/accordion][/accordions]

item.title: Commencement
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Participants

All participants must report with your academic regalia to rooms 100 and 170 of the College of Law for marshalling at 3:30 p.m. Tricia Rackliffe, College of Law Registrar, will meet you and point out your position in the processional. After receiving these instructions, you will proceed to the Sports Arena for the official processional. During the hooding portion of the ceremony, when your name is announced, you should proceed to the hooding station where selected members of the faculty will affix an academic hood to your regalia. The ceremony itself will last approximately 90 minutes.

Regalia

All participants are required to wear appropriate academic regalia. Regalia will be available for rental from the University bookstore by ordering online. (Choose "Cap and Gown For All Students" to find Georgia State's regalia.) The rental cost is $144 for your regalia which includes cap, gown, hood and tassel. For more information, contact the bookstore directly at 404-413-9700.

Deadline to Order

The first deadline to order regalia online is mid-February. Pickup is at the Student Center Ballroom in late March. Online ordering can continue through March 28 with a pickup at the bookstore in May.  The bookstore may have extras on hand, but cannot guarantee preferred size.

Guest Admission and Announcements

Tickets are not required for admission and there are no reserved seats. Students will receive 15 free graduation announcements with parking and direction cards, which are available for pick-up at the reception desk in March.

Extracurriculars and Hooding Team Ballot Form

Each student is entitled to list up to four extracurricular activities in the official Commencement and Hooding Ceremony program. Please complete this form and include the official titles of the organizations or extracurricular activities you want to appear in the program. In addition, each year the graduating class votes to decide which professors will serve on the hooding team. In order for your vote to be counted and for your law school organizations or activities to be listed in program, you must complete the form and return it by March 15.

Parking

On the afternoon of the ceremony, parking will be available for your guests for a fee of $7.00 per vehicle in parking lots K, N and S. See map below for details. Guests should allow at least 30 minutes for parking and entry into the Sports Arena. A parking map will be included in your invitations. For information on handicap parking accommodations contact Georgia State University Auxiliary Services at 404-413-9500.

Thank you for your 2014 Ben F. Johnson Public Service Award nomination. You will receive an email confirmation to the email address you provided. To complete your nomination, submit a full nomination letter not exceeding 2,500 words and other supporting documentation via e-mail to award@gsulaw.net. To submit additional files at a later date, e-mail to award@gsulaw.net with the nominee's name in the subject line. Return to the Ben F. Johnson Award page.

item.title: Study Space VII Application
item.dc:creator: adminwp
item.content:encoded:
Thank you for your interest in Study Space VII, Beyond Affordable Housing:  An Interdisciplinary Multinational Approach to Adequate Housing Options.  This program will take place in Barcelona, Spain from May 5-9, 2014. Please complete the online form below to be considered for one of the available spaces.  Participants will be accepted on a rolling basis so early application is encouraged.  The deadline to apply to the program is February 7, 2014 at midnight EST.

Once accepted into the program, a deposit of $450 will be due within 2 weeks; this deposit is refundable until March 7, 2014. The balance of the program fee ($450) will be due by April 1, 2014 and is non-refundable.

Please note that the $900 program fee includes scheduled group meals, speaker honoraria, and field visits.  Hotel, airline tickets, and airport ground transportation must be purchased separately.  A block of hotel rooms will be reserved Sunday through Friday nights and is estimated to be $850 including breakfast each day. Participants will be responsible for booking their hotel rooms by Tuesday, February 11. Passports and visas, if required, will be the responsibility of the individual participant. [form form-study-space]

item.title: Study Space VII Application
item.dc:creator: adminwp
item.content:encoded:
Thank you

Thank you for applying to Study Space VII, Beyond Affordable Housing:  An Interdisciplinary Multinational Approach to Adequate Housing Options, which will take place in Barcelona, Spain from May 5-9, 2014.

You will receive an email within 1 week that indicates whether you have been accepted into the program. A deposit of $450 will be due within 2 weeks of acceptance; this deposit is refundable until March 7, 2014. The balance of the program fee ($450) will be due by April 1, 2014 and is non-refundable.  

A block of hotel rooms has been reserved.  You are responsible for booking your hotel room by February 11, 2014.  You are responsible for paying the hotel directly for your stay.
